content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

I fail to see what's interesting about this badly formulated problem.

> Output a single integer representing the squared sum of the minutes taken to reach A, B, and C. If the result is a decimal value, it should be rounded down to the nearest integer.

The "result" referred to in the last sentence is the squared sum of the minutes. For the input of "80\n10 30 20" this means taking the sum of 7.5 + 22.5 + 15, squaring and flooring it, which results in 2025. Nowhere does the statement mention that you're also supposed to round down the minutes in each individual segment (so that it becomes 7 + 22 + 15). Note that for the input of "61\n1 1 1" the expected result is 0 because I guess it takes zero minutes to travel one kilometer three times.

I played this in fastest, but ended up playing as if it's the reverse mode (which is disabled here, ironically). How this was approved is beyond me.

It's an interesting clash with a mathematical formula to guess or to search.

I tried it with C# and the tests worked.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Clash, it is formatted much better now. The clash is interesting and requires thought and "bing search" to solve.

Nice Job!
Code-Parser

Please format as follows:

INPUT:

<<Line 1:>> Variable [[s]], for speed.
<<Line 2:>> Three distances [[A]], [[B]], and [[C]].

OUTPUT:

<<Line 1:>> Output a single integer representing the squared sum of the minutes taken to reach [[A]], [[B]], and [[C]]. If the result is a decimal value, it should be rounded down to the nearest integer. For example, if the result is {{5.9}}, it should be rounded to {{5}}.

CONSTRAINTS:

1 < [[A]], [[B]], [[C]] < 100

Thanks,
Code-Parser

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I tried it few times, it's easy to understand and do. All you need is logical thinking and google for formulas.
Do not approve yet! Still has stuff to fix.

On top of @Code-Parser's advice:

Input
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[s]], for speed.
<<Line 2:>> Three space-separated integers [[A]], [[B]], and [[C]] for the distances.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Task
* I don't understand: why should the time to take be squared before output? That seems such an arbitrary requirement.

Thanks.
Good point, sorry for that. I edited the task. Thanks.
Good advice. Please follow @5DN1L's advice, as it is clearer.
It is squared to be a bit more challenging or interesting, thanks for the advices! I fixed some stuff. Thanks again.

Right all stuff fixed now. 

@TINKO LASKOS, Logic! Yes to LOGIC... just want you to know that "Bing search" is much better than Google search, when looking for formulas.

Cheerio!
Code-Parser.
